pgTitle: List of statutory minimum employment leave by country

rows.text: 14 calendar days (from 0 to 5 years seniority), 21 calendar days (from 5 to 10), 28 calendar days (from 10 to 20) and 35 calendar days (from 20)
14 days after 1 year employment, 21 day after 5 years employment
20 days, premium pay, plus 10 public holidays
22 working days ( 1 month vacation, counting the weekends too), with 33% extra pay, after 1 year employment, of which 10 can be sold back to the employer. In addition, holidays are also paid.
20 working days and up to 12 days national and public holidays
Determined by provincial law. Minimum 10 working days depending on province and tenure of employment. In addition, 5–10 public holidays depending on province.
5 working days (from 1 to 9 years seniority), 10 working days (from 10 to 19), 15 working days (from 20 years onwards).
15 working days for every year, vacations can be accumulated for up to 4 years (up to 60 working days of vacations). Plus 18 Public Holidays
20 working days of leave for workers on a five-day week and 24 working days of leave for workers on a six-day week over a period of one year's employment.
14 work days after one year employment, 20 work days after 5 years employment.

28 calendar days (public holidays not included), unless employer and employee agree over a longer vacation; up to 56 calendar days for selected education and science professionals (determined by government decree).

5 weeks (30 days with Saturdays, but not Sundays counted as holidays) is the minimum mandated by law. More precisely: vacation is accrued between April to March each year and used primarily during the following summer holiday period. During each such full period 2.5 vacation days are accrued per month. When taking up a new job, only 2 days are accrued until the start of the first full period. Many trade unions have been able to agree for more vacation time for their profession
20 working days or more depending on the years in the company
7 days(1 to 2 years), Add one day per year until 14 days (3+ years)
20 working days (increasing up to 30 with age)
1 work day for every 20 days worked (around 12 work days a year)
12 days, it varies from 1 company to another but normally it's 12 work days per year.

14 working days for the first 4 years. 16 days from the 5th year. 18 days from the 6th year, and 21 days from the 7th year. from the 8th year an additional day is added per year up to 28 days. not including official holidays, sick leave, etc.

At least 20 working days (exact amount depends on contract details, a few contracts guarantee up to 25 days), entirely paid, plus up to 104 hours of ROL, that means reduction of working time (in Italian Riduzione Orario di Lavoro), that have to be used primarily in blocks of a few hours each time for family/personal needs (for example bringing a kid to the doctor, going to the bank etc.) but may be utilized as well, just for the unused part of them and just if the company/the collective contract allows that, to get additional vacation hours/days, or to shorten of 1 or 2 hours the working day on Fridays. Furthermore, there are 12–13 paid public holidays.
From 10 working days for the first year to 20 days for the 6th year.
At least 25 working days; 10 public holidays.

Starts at 8 days for first 2 years employment with an employer. Increases to 12 days for between 2 and 5 years employment and 16 days for 5 or more years. Plus, depending on which state, around 14 public holidays.

Starts at minimum 6 days for the 1 year of employment. Increases to 8 days after the second year, to 10 days after the third year, 12 days after the fourth year, and to 14 days from year 5 to year 9; then every 5 years increases two days.

15 working days for the 1 year of employment. Increase up to 29 working days after 32 years of employment. 48 working days paid vacation for teachers and professors for all levels of school, kindergarten and university regardless of the number of years of service.
21 consecutive days, or 1.75 days for every 1 month worked, plus 14 days paid public Holidays. Some companies do increase leave amounts, depending on how long the employee has worked at the company.
4 weeks plus 9 paid public holidays (not compensated if they fall during the weekend).
4 weeks as of April 1, 2007, plus 11–12 paid public holidays, depending on which day they fall. Employees can cash up to 1 week of annual holidays per year
30 consecutive days plus 10 paid public holidays.
30 calendar days, which includes weekend days. Effectively, 20 to 22 working days.
5 days, rendered at least 1 year of service is entitled to a yearly service incentive leave.
20 working days per year during the first 10 years of employment and 26 working days thereafter. Plus 13 days of public holidays.
22 working days, with 100% extra pay. Plus all public holidays that are also paid.
21 working days plus 12 paid public holidays (not compensated if they fall during the weekend).

28 calendar days (52 in extreme north regions) {for militaries 30/45 days except for drafted}, plus 12 public holidays (they neither count nor pay) There is the 10-nonbankdays streak in January (6 of them are holidays).
20 working days minimum (effectively 4 weeks, law defines working week as 5 working days for purpose of paid vacation), plus 9 bank holidays and up to two more days depending on religion of employee.
21 working day and 30 days after 5 years of employment.
For regular employees, 7 days with 1 additional day per year up to a maximum of 14 days. No statutory minimum leave for seamen, domestic workers, or employees in managerial or executive positions.
20 days, 25 days after reaching the age of 33 years.
20 working days of leave and 13 public holidays.

21 consecutive days, or 1 day for every 17 days worked, or 1 hour for every 17 hours worked, not including 12 public holidays. Regular workers may take a further 3 days of family responsibility leave. Leave legislation does not apply to members of the National Defence Force, National Intelligence Agency, South African Secret Service or unpaid volunteers working for a charity.
22 work days, not including 14 public holidays.
28 working days: 14 maximum annual, 7 casual, and 7 sick leave.

25 work days minimum, plus 13 public holidays (some of which fall on a Saturday or a Sunday) and three de facto holidays (two of which may fall on a Saturday or a Sunday). Additional leave, often called arbetstidsförkortning (English: shortening of work time), typically 5-10 work days per year, is available for many Swedish employees.

At least 20 work days, plus 12–16 public holidays (some of which always fall on a Sunday). People working in the public sector usually benefit of an additional paid week off; a few companies offer the same benefit to their employees after some years of service.
0 days (from 0 to 1 year), 7 days (from 1 to 3 years), 10 days (3 to 5 years), 14 days (5 to 10 years), Add one day per year until 30 days (10+ years)
14 work days for 0–5 years, 20 work days for 5–15 years and 26 days for over 15 years seniority.
24 calendar days (6 months - 1 year of employment); 30 calendar days (>1 year of employment). This is in addition to 10 paid public holidays.
28 calendar days (5.6 weeks) These may include the Bank/Public holidays which otherwise would be unpaid.
20 working days (from 0 to 5 years seniority), 21 calendar days (from 5 to 8). Afterwards, an additional working day is added every four years.
15 paid days for the first year and 1 day extra for every year of service up to 30 days. In addition, a maximum of 12 public holidays provided every holiday falls on a weekday.
